keyTakeAways: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a significant global outage that disrupted internet services worldwide, including social media, gaming, financial platforms, and education tools.
The outage originated from a domain name system (DNS) issue within AWS’s US-EAST-1 region, which caused websites and apps to fail to load.
Services such as Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, Signal, and Canvas were affected, illustrating the widespread dependency on AWS infrastructure.
Educational platforms like Canvas were unusable for students and faculty, with institutions like the University of California, Riverside and Ohio State University reporting disrupted online learning.
The incident highlights how modern society is increasingly dependent on just a few tech companies for foundational internet infrastructure, making global systems vulnerable to single-point failures.
Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess describe such outages as typical, non-cyberattack-related, and usually resolved within hours through standard technical processes.
This is not the first such incident; AWS has had multiple outages in 2017, 2020, 2021, and 2023, indicating recurring risks in cloud computing reliability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) suffered a major global outage on Monday, October 20, 2025, which began at around 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and lasted until approximately 6 p.m. Eastern time. The root cause was identified as a failure in AWS's domain name system (DNS) in the US-EAST-1 region, leading to widespread disruptions across services including social media (Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite), financial platforms (Robinhood, Coinbase), streaming services (Netflix, Disney+), and education tools (Canvas). Users of Amazon's own products like Ring and Alexa also reported outages. The incident highlighted the extreme fragility of modern internet infrastructure, as society has become heavily reliant on just a few tech giants like Amazon, whose infrastructure underpins critical services. Experts such as Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess noted that such outages are typically non-cyberattack-related, resolve within hours, and follow established recovery processes. This is not the first time AWS has experienced such outages—previous incidents in 2017, 2020, and 2021 have demonstrated recurring vulnerabilities. The event serves as a stark reminder of the risks associated with centralized control of essential digital services.
title: Amazon Cloud Outage Exposes Internet’s Fragile Backbone
